Comments_List: This course not only is a wonderful exposure to important issues in education and more generally in society at large, but offers a strong foundation from which to approach further law/policy related courses and work.
We learned a great deal about the history of American education and the legal principles that are relevant in settling various disputes.
Through this course, I explored the body of case law governing our education system and learned to apply precedent to analyze  legal situations in schools.

I think one of the most fruitful exercises of this course was teaching us how to apply case law to various hypothetical problems in the book. In contrast to other law courses I've taken at Yale, in which we have simply read and memorized cases, this course enabled me to really engage with the material, write papers in which I was asking and grappling with questions that interested me, and think about the application of case law in the real world.
So many, I have such a better understanding of American law specifically related to education

This course has become the benchmark with which I assess truly exceptional class experiences. Everything from choosing how and when to fulfill the paper requirement to the arc and thematic organization of the course was brilliant.

My one comment would be to perhaps focus more time in class on the application and discussion phase of the seminar. It was very helpful that Judge Garfinkel spoke to the historical significance of many of the cases and issues we discussed, but at times I found myself wanting to grapple with some of these challenging issues head on on a more regular basis.

Judge Garfinkel is a strong instructor.  He always leads riveting class discussions, and the feedback he provided on my writing/legal analyses over the term has immensely helpful to my growth.  I highly recommend taking any opportunity you have to learn from Judge Garfinkelhe truly makes this course special.

I think the flexibility of the course is a strength, as it is rare at Yale to find professors who trust students enough to create their own deadlines and submit original work that is not based off of a specific prompt. That really forced me to think about what we had read and how I wished to engage with it. In addition, I liked that on some days Judge Garfinkel taught the course as if it were a real law course, cold-calling students on the facts and holdings of cases.

Strengths: Judge Garfinkle is so knowledgeable and experienced, and he also cares a lot about and engages with students thoughts and questions. The reading was super interesting to me, because Ive been interested in education issues and it was neat to have a purely legal perspective. 

Weaknesses: Class time could strike a better balance between Judge Garfinkle lecturing about the cases and student/class discussion.
Judge Garfinkel made the course great
